title: Drivers on the M1 face speed limit of 60mph in bid to cut pollution under radical plans
text:

Drivers on the M1 could see speed limits slashed to 60mph in a bid to reduce pollution under plans being considered by Highways England. 
The reduced limit would come into force during rush hour periods along a stretch of motorway which runs close to schools and homes in Sheffield. 
Air pollution in the area between junction 28-35a already breaches UK and EU limits hundreds of times a year, but the problem is set to get worse due to plans by the Department for Transport to open a new smart motorway. 
The £106m scheme will add 5,000 to 10,000 vehicles a day to the 130,000 already using the road by opening the hard shoulder. The London to Leeds south-north motorway already breaches UK and EU pollution limits (Photo: Birmingham Mail) Read More 8,000 drivers caught using handheld mobile phones at the wheel during one week 
Reports commissioned by Highways England have forecast the scheme could increase residents’ exposure to pollution by such an extent it would make it illegal. 
One of the reports, which was carried out by engineering consultancy Mouchel, said: “Air quality assessment predicted that operating at 70mph, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, would result in significant adverse impacts on air quality”. 
Highways England is now under pressure to find an alternative way to bring down pollution levels. 
Last month the organisation’s operations director Nick Harris wrote to local MPs saying: “We are looking into initiatives that might avoid or reduce the need for these speed limits.” The motorway is causing devastating levels of pollution in the Sheffield area (Photo: Rex Features) Read More Spot the problem with these road signs: motorists left scratching their heads over highway notices gaffe 
One of those initiatives, which involved painting barriers with “catalytic paints” designed to remove pollutants from the air, has already been unsuccessful. 
An AA spokesman said the proposal could provoke anger among road users, who will face fines if they exceed 60mph. 
He said: “Car users are always the easy hit when it comes to pollution when actually they are not one of the main contributors. 
There will be people raising their eyebrows about whether this is just an example of the authorities trying to look like they are doing something. It is feared that the new 60mph limit would anger drivers, the AA is warning (Photo: Getty) 
“There will be a section of car users, who will see that this is not safety-related, and that they are being penalised for emissions that are likely to have come from other sources as well. 
“That same section will say they pay billions of pounds in taxes … and if we’re contributing that amount of money why isn’t it being spent on the road network to deal with the issues?” 
He added: “There is a very good chance that the traffic is already moving at that speed during rush-hour.” Like us on Facebook
